title: Italy’s 5Stars, center left close to forming alliance, officials say
text:
According to two PD officials and one government aide from the 5Stars, Zingaretti and 5Stars leader Luigi Di Maio that Giuseppe Conte should remain prime minister | Andreas Solaro/AFP via Getty Images Italy’s 5Stars, center left close to forming alliance, officials say President Mattarella is expected to announce a way out of the government crisis on Wednesday evening.

ROME — An agreement to form a new Italian government is within reach between the center-left Democratic Party and populist 5Star Movement, officials said Monday as the president prepared to launch marathon talks Tuesday aimed at solving the government crisis.

Two officials from the Democratic Party (PD) said talks are moving along after a brief meeting between the two party leaders Monday afternoon, and a deal would include agreement on reappointing Giuseppe Conte as prime minister.

President Sergio Mattarella is on Tuesday set to begin a new 36 hour-long round of consultations with political groups to try to find a way out of the current political crisis, which began earlier this month when far-right League leader Matteo Salvini pulled the plug on his coalition government with the 5Stars and called for a vote of confidence in Prime Minister Conte, who later announced his resignation. Mattarella is expected to announce a way out of the government crisis on Wednesday evening.

Mattarella is now tasked with deciding the way forward, including whether to call a snap election or instal a new government based on an alternative majority in parliament.

One of the sticking points in discussions about a potential PD-5Stars alliance had been Conte’s political future. Initially, PD leader Nicola Zingaretti ruled out reappointing Conte, who is not affiliated with any party, saying Italy needs a clean break from the previous government. The 5Stars, who are currently the biggest party in the Italian parliament, had said they would not budge on his name.

But according to the two PD officials and one government aide from the 5Star Movement, Zingaretti and 5Star leader Luigi Di Maio agreed Monday that Conte should remain prime minister. They also said the two sides are currently considering either former Prime Minister Paolo Gentiloni, currently the PD’s president, or MEP Roberto Gualtieri, a member of the PD, as candidates to be Italy's next European commissioner.

All three people also said Rome has asked European Commission President-elect Ursula von der Leyen to give Italy more time to propose a candidate to join her team.

After the official government collapse last week, Salvini had told Mattarella he is willing to make peace with the 5Stars and form a new government with them to prevent them from teaming up with the PD. But on Monday night, Salvini seemed to have given up on that idea and said during a press conference he is "proud" to have pulled the plug on the coalition government, accusing his former partners of scheming against him to rule with the PD for a long time.

A PD-5Star coalition would make the League Italy’s biggest opposition party, but polls predict the League would gain parliamentary seats in a new election.
